utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: What brings you in here today.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I I've had this cough that's been ongoing and and getting worse, and and now I've been having this like sharp pain in my in my chest.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and when did the cough first start?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So yeah, like the cough started, uh, started maybe a couple of weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: A couple weeks ago, OK, and has it gotten worse since then, or has it stayed about the same?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh it, it got worse initially, but it's been about the, uh, well, actually yeah, it's been getting worse 'cause now I've I've started to notice blood in the sputum that wasn't there at first.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and when did you first notice that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So I, I first saw some blood, uhm, two days ago. It was a really small amount so I didn't worry too much, but I I brought up blood yesterday and again this morning. It's been just about enough to cover a tissue, so it's not a lot of blood each time, but it's pretty red.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and before that were you getting any production throughout your coughs for the last few weeks, like were you producing any sputum?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, OK. Can you just describe your cough currently? Is it more of a wet cough or dry cough?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh it, yeah, it's it's dry mostly with the exception of bringing up some of the blood.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And is the blood just in like sputum that you're bringing up? Or are you coughing up blood into the tissue, for example?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Blood is, I'm coughing that up into the tissue.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you remember 2 weeks ago prior to that, were there any factors that might have caused this, like for example, did you travel anywhere or see or was in contact with anyone that was sick?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No I haven't uh, traveled anywhere. I have been doing volunteering and and things at the homeless shelter here in in town. It's been really cold out.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, uh, and how long have you been volunteering there?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, I started this winter, so the last three, three or four months.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and were you in contact with anyone there that was sick or was having similar symptoms at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: There are certainly some people around that that had some that would have a cough, or were not feeling very well but, uh, and sometimes I would see people who would even have a hospital gown on, that that that uh came from the hospital. So yeah, there were definitely some people who weren't feeling well.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you know if anyone at the homeless shelter or anywhere else around your surrounding has had tuberculosis?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, not that I'm aware of. I haven't heard of that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, are you having any other symptoms at all besides the the coughing and the blood, like coughing up blood as well?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I've been uh, starting to get like this sharp chest pain as well. I kind of feel it on the left sides and in center I guess kinda more so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and your chest pain, when did that start?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So, uh, this started, yeah, 'bout a few days ago as well. It's been within the last week.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and uh, would you describe it as, so you said it's kind of a sharp pain, does it move around anywhere?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, the pain I feel it about in the same spot each time.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and are you feeling the pain when you're coughing or is it when you're exerting yourself, like when do you feel the pain, and how long does it last?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I, yeah, I will feel it when I cough. I also feel it uh, if I'm maybe moving around as well. Like changing positions or things like that. It hurts for a few minutes and then it it will kind of settle down. If if I'm, if I stay stationary and sort of lean forward a little bit it will it will start to feel better.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Sort of feels better? OK, and besides, besides like leaning forward, has anything helped reduce that pain at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, well if I lie flat, uhm it, it's uh, or sorry. No actually, the pain gets worse if I I lie flat or if I'm if I'm taking a deep breath in. But really, the only thing that helps the pain is if I try to lean forward when I'm sitting down.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, I see, and do you have any pain when breathing in or out?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I do, yeah it it gets worse if I if I'm taking a deep breath in, and even more so after I after I cough, if I'm trying to catch my breath, I'll feel it then too.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and uhm, other than these symptoms, do you have any kind of shortness of breath? Do you have any dizziness or increased sweating, any of those symptoms?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I have been sweating at night, but, uh, yeah that's it.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And how about any fevers or chills?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I I have felt a bit hot. That's more so yeah, maybe when I've been having night sweats, but I feel OK now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and when you say night sweats, are your sheets and blankets like soaked your pillows?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, there there have been a few few nights for sure, but it doesn't happen every night. But over these last several months, it's been weird, I've woken up soaked.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, uh, do you have any other symptoms like a headache or nausea, vomiting?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Have you measured a temperature at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm no I haven't.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, we can do that today. Do you have any other symptoms like feeling like pounding your chest, racing heart, anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Have you noticed any swelling in your extremities, like your legs and hands?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you have any issues with your bowel movements? Any Constipation or diarrhea?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any urinary issues?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any issues with your sleep and appetite?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no. Sleep's been OK, and I've been eating well, but I have uhm, lost some weight and and I've been more fatigued over the last couple months.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Before the two weeks or a couple of weeks that you had this, were you sick at all recently? Like with a cold or any flu like symptoms?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I I uh, I guess I've been fatigued over the last couple of months, but I haven't had any flu like symptoms.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you have any exposure to dust, fumes, animals anywhere in your surrounding?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I do have uh, two cats at home, but I've had them for seven years now and I've been tested for allergies and and I'm clear there.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK? Do you live with anyone right now?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I live with my husband and we have three daughters as well.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and are any of them sick at all or have any similar symptoms.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, my my husband's had a cough uh, as well, he hasn't brought up any blood or anything though. But my my daughters have felt OK.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you have any past medical diagnosis like high blood pressure, diabetes, asthma, anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah I do have uh, type 2 diabetes, as well as high blood pressure. I've been diagnosed with depression before as well. I do take a few medications for diabetes and blood pressure. I'm not on insulin though.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you know what medications you take?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I think an ACE inhibitor and, and I think Ramipril and uh, metformin.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you take anything for depression?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I used to take a a citalopram, but I stopped and and things have been been stable.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: That's good. Any hospitalizations or surgeries in the past?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I had two C sections for my second daughter and and 3rd.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any complications at all with those C sections?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, everything was was good.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any other surgeries or hospitalizations?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, do you have any family history of any lung conditions, heart conditions, any cancers?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: My dad had a stroke when he was in his late 60s, but that's the only thing I can think of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and I know you said you volunteer at the homeless shelter, but do you do anything else for work at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I've been doing some administrative work from from home because of covid, so with the extra time I've been trying to to do some extra volunteering.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: That's really good. And so besides, so you live with your husband and three kids, does anyone in smoke in the house or do you smoke at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I don't. No one smokes in the house.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, does, uh, do you take any recreational drugs like marijuana?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And how about alcohol?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Sometimes I'll have some like red wine with dinner, but that's only on like Christmas or an occasion.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Yeah, alright so uh other than that, sorry, I think I might have forgotten to ask you a couple questions. So no fainting spells, no shortness of breath, nothing like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I haven't had anything like that, just a stern cough.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and no chest pain on exertion?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, it's the chest pain, well, I guess if I'm like moving around a lot, but it's not, it doesn't come on uh, like because of like physical activity. I just feel it like anytime I'm, like when I'm breathing in or even just moving my body around in the chair.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And any like fatigue or increased tiredness.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I've had some fatigue for sure.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have you lost any weight recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I I have actually. I'm I'm down 20 pounds. I thought that was great. I I was 200 pounds just two months ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And have you been trying to lose weight or that 20 pounds just went away spontaneously?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, I mean I I guess I've tried to make changes to my diet here and there because of the diabetes, but I don't really think that it would be enough to lose 20 pounds.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, I see. Yeah so, do you have any questions? Those are all the questions I have. Do you have any questions or concerns?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I was just, I guess just concerned about the the blood in the, in the cough.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, so definitely that's something concerning. We want to make sure there was no, so you work at a homeless shelter, where there may be a tuberculosis case, and your symptoms of coughing up blood as well as losing a significant weight recently, and some of the other symptoms that you described as well, point towards uh TB as one of the causes. No lung cancer history right, in your family?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, uhm so we definitely want to do testing for TB. Will do us a smear today of your sputum and we will, since you have been in contact with your family, we will have to contact a public health if the tests come back positive, and it seems that, we'll also do some other testing. Sometimes with tuberculosis you can get something called pericarditis, and some of the symptoms you are having may point to pericarditis as well, so we might have to do an EKG. We might have to further do an ultrasound, an x-ray, for example. So first we'll just get the TB test done and then if it comes back positive, you will need to isolate, be admitted to the hospital as well, and be on a course of antibiotics. So I know this is a lot to take in. Do you have any questions or concerns at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Not right now. Guess will wait until some of the results come back and yeah, get started.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, so we'll just do the TB test first, alright?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Alright, thank you.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
